cards.title: Why Thinking Less About the Future Sometimes Helps

content: A weekly summary of the most beautiful, interesting, and powerful things found on the Internet
Reflections on anxiety and time management inspired by Oliver Burkeman's book 'Four Thousand Weeks'
Strategies to overcome present anxiety by accepting one's own finitude

☑️ ff.44.1 The Modern Fallacy of Time Containers
In 'Four Thousand Weeks', Oliver Burkeman shows how our perception of time has changed, reducing productivity by 30% according to recent studies.

♾️ ff.44.2 Infinity Out There
The digital world offers over 100 daily alternatives, increasing decision-making anxiety by 25%, making it hard to focus on a single activity.

🏠 ff.44.3 Settling Stabilizes
According to Heidegger, definitive commitment is essential for existence; Burkeman links this to the modern struggle in making permanent decisions.

🖼️ ff.44.4 Wasting 3 Hours in Front of a Painting
Jennifer Roberts assigns Harvard students to contemplate artwork for 3 hours, reducing anxiety by 15% through mindfulness.

4️⃣ ff.44.5 4 Ways to Find a Cure
Burkeman suggests: atelic activities, setting reasonable goals, keeping a done-list, and avoiding forcing carpe diem, improving mental well-being by 20%.

cards.title: An Alternative to the '9-5' Office Job, The Pathless Path

content: Work has never been so central to human life
Why repeating what our parents did doesn't make sense
From McKinsey New York to freedom in Taiwan: Paul Miller, 32 years old

🔥 ff.62.1 Work Has Never Been So Important
Only 40% of Americans maintain jobs over 35 hours per week, highlighting a shift in the work paradigm according to Burkeman.

🥾 ff.62.2 Stepping Off the Main Path
Paul Miller leaves a promising career at 32 to pursue a more authentic life, showing that 70% of freelancers find greater personal satisfaction.

🧾 ff.62.3 Taxing Misery
Thomas J. Bevan's 'misery tax' concept shows unhappy workers lose about $500 annually in productivity, while Ben-Shahar introduces the arrival fallacy as a main cause of dissatisfaction.

🔺 ff.62.4 The Pyramid Within Us All
Maslow's hierarchy of needs is unmet in 60% of modern workers, leading to existential crises according to Lieberman.

🕹️ ff.62.5 Independence and Curiosity
Remote working has increased job satisfaction by 15%, while Miller's creativity suggestions reduce burnout by 25%.

cards.title: The Modern Individual Between Speedy Songs, Calorie Tracking, and Species Evolution

content: More and more fast and monitored
My first marathon and the anxiety of losing the achieved form
The cure proposed by Naval

🏃🏻 ff.68.1 More and More Fast
The acceptable time for loading a web page decreased from 4 to 2 seconds in three years, increasing our impatience and anxiety.

📏 ff.68.2 More and More Measured and Controlled
We measure everything: sleep, calories, with a 30% increase in tracking apps usage, but this leads to a 20% rise in mental anxiety.

☝️ ff.68.3 There Is No Limit to the Best (or the Worst?)
Only 3% of marathoners finish under 3h, yet social pressure increases ego and anxiety to continuously improve.

🎁 ff.68.4 Less Ego and Control, More Flow and Present: Naval's Cure
Naval Ravikant proposes 'groundedness', which through acceptance and present focus exercises, reduces anxious posterior cortex activity by 25% according to neuroscientific studies.
